'''Rúmil''' was a [[Noldor]]in sage of [[Tirion]],<ref name=":2">[[J.R.R. Tolkien]], [[Christopher Tolkien]] (ed.), ''[[The Silmarillion]]'', "[[Quenta Silmarillion]]", "Index", ''Rúmil''</ref> one of the [[Lambengolmor]] ("Loremasters")<ref name="WJ">{{WJ|Quendi}}, pp. 396-8</ref> of the Noldor and first deviser of written characters.<ref name=":2" />

==History==
Rúmil was notable for inventing a writing system that was fitting for the recording of speech and song, some for graving upon metal or stone, others for drawing with brush or with pen.<ref name=":0">{{S|Feanor}}</ref>

His alphabet was called both ''Tengwar of Rúmil'' ("Letters of Rúmil")<ref name=":1">{{App|Writing}}</ref> and ''[[Sarati]]'', as each letter was called a ''sarat''.<ref name="WJ" /><ref>{{B|III}}, p. 100</ref> The Tengwar of Rúmil was not used in Middle-earth and was later expanded and perfected by [[Fëanor]]<ref name=":0" /> as the [[Tengwar|Tengwar of Fëanor]] ("Letters of Fëanor"), more commonly known as simply Tengwar.<ref name=":1" />

Based on when Rúmil's work in the [[Annals of Valinor]] ends, it was suggested that he was one of the Noldor who initially joined the [[Exile]], but then returned to Valinor with [[Finarfin]].<ref>{{LR|AV}}</ref>{{rp|99}}

Rúmil continued his studies from Aman for many thousands of years beyond the [[fall of Gondolin]].<ref name="Lhammas" />{{rp|154}} He continued to document the evolution of language among the three clans in Aman,<ref name="Lhammas" />{{rp|145}} as well as what he had learned of languages from [[Middle-earth]], such as [[Khuzdul|Dwarvish]].<ref name="Lhammas">{{LR|Lhammas}}</ref>{{rp|144}}<ref group="note">A note specifically attributed to Rúmil, in his writings concerning the speeches of the earth of old, is ''"of the language of the Dwarves little is known to us, save that its origin is as dark as is the origin of the Dwarvish race itself; and their tongues are not akin to other tongues, but wholly alien, and they are harsh and intricate, and few have essayed to learn them"''; to this Pengolodh adds an interjection of his hearing of Aulë first making the Dwarves and teaching them language.</ref>

==Works==
Rúmil was said to be the author of various works, some of which would find [[The Silmarillion|great acknowledgment]] after they were translated into [[Westron]] by [[Bilbo Baggins]]. These include:
*''[[Ainulindalë (Rúmil's work)|Ainulindalë]]''<ref>[[J.R.R. Tolkien]], [[Christopher Tolkien]] (ed.), ''[[The Silmarillion]]'', "[[Quenta Silmarillion]]", "Index", ''Ainulindalë''</ref>
*''[[Annals of Valinor]]''
*''[[Lhammas]]''
*''[[Lhammasethen]]''
*''[[Ambarkanta|Ambarkanta: The Shape of the World]]''<ref>{{LT1|Foreword}}</ref>
*''[[i Equessi Rumilo]]''

[[Pengolodh]] of [[Gondolin]] continued and completed much of Rúmil's work.

==Etymology==
The only thing known about the name ''Rúmil'' is that it is [[Quenya]].<ref>{{PE|17}}, pp. 51, 54</ref>

[[Christopher Tolkien]] speculated that it is likely to be connected with the [[Gnomish]] words ''rû'' and ''rûm'' ("secret, mystery"), ''ruim'' ("secret, mysterious"), ''rui'' ("whisper") and/or ''ruitha'' ("to whisper").<ref>{{LT1|Appendix}}, entry "Rúmil"</ref>{{rp|345}}

==Other versions of the legendarium==
===Book of Lost Tales===
In ''[[The Book of Lost Tales]]'', Rúmil was the [[Gnome]] Door-ward of [[Cottage of Lost Play|Mar Vanwa Tyaliéva]] and the narrator of many tales including ''[[The Music of the Ainur]]'', ''[[The Coming of the Valar and the Building of Valinor]]'', and ''[[The Flight of the Noldoli]]'' (along with [[Lindo]]).

He is described as old in appearance and grey of locks.<ref name="link">{{LT1|Link}}</ref> The character [[Littleheart]] referred to him as "Rúmil the Sage"<ref name="valar">{{LT1|III}}</ref>{{rp|82}} and [[Christopher Tolkien]] described him as "the garrulous and whimsical philologist of [[Kortirion]]".<ref>{{LT1|LinkC}}</ref>{{rp|61}} 

In the distant past ("a lifetime gone") Rúmil was a resident of [[Kôr]].<ref name="link">{{LT1|Link}}</ref>{{rp|60}} In the [[Great Lands]], long before the [[Fall of Gondolin]], he was a slave under [[Melko]].<ref name="link" />{{rp|59}} He was not one of the first Elves as, when describing the [[Music of the Ainur]], he claims his knowledge of it originated from [[Manwë]] whispering it to "the fathers of my father in the deeps of time".<ref name="music">{{LT1|Music}}</ref>{{rp|66}}

Rúmil was very learned in languages. During his days in Kôr he learned much of the "secret tongue" [[Valarin|of the Valar]] by the goodness of [[Aulë]]. He was aware of the distinctions between the various [[Elvish|Elven tongues]] of the Teleri (later [[Vanyar#Other versions of the legendarium|Vanyar]]), Noldoli, [[Solosimpi]], and the [[Inwir]] (the royal clan ''within'' the Teleri). While a slave under Melko, he lightened his thraldom by learning the speech of all monsters and goblins. He further conned even the speeches of beasts including voles, mice, and beetles. He worried at whiles over the tongues of [[Men]], but disliked them due to their propensity to change and of being a "hard stuff whereof to labour songs or tales".<ref name="link" />{{rp|59–60}}

Rúmil does not appear directly in ''[[The Book of Lost Tales: Part Two]]'', however he and his work, "the book of Rúmil", is frequently cited in the Appendix defining names.

In a later draft of [[Meril-i-Turinqi| Meril-i-Turinqi's]] ''"[[The Chaining of Melko]]"'', Tolkien apparently intended to replace Rúmil with '''''Evromord the Door-ward''''' of Mar Vanwa Tyaliéva.<ref>{{LT1|IVn}}, p. 107 note 3</ref>

===The Lost Road===
In the 1930's version of the ''[[Ainulindalë (Lost Road)|Ainulindalë]]'', [[Ælfwine]] (Eriol) still heard the story of the Music of the Ainur from Rúmil’s own lips in Tol Eressëa.<ref>{{LR|Ainu}}, p. 133, note 1</ref>

==Portrayal in adaptations==
'''2024: ''[[The Lord of the Rings: The Rings of Power]]'', Season Two:'''
:'''Episode 2: ''[[Where the Stars are Strange]]'':'''
::At the [[Grey Havens]], [[Círdan]] metaphorically asks [[Elrond]] if he would "cast Rúmil's verses into" flames just "because the poet was a drunkard" to metaphorically explain that just because [[Sauron]] had a role in the making of the [[Three Rings]], doesn’t mean that the rings are wholly evil.
:'''Episode 7: ''Doomed to Die:'''''
::At the [[Sack of Eregion]], [[Adar (The Rings of Power)|Adar]] asks Elrond if he had forgotten "his Rúmil": "never make war in anger".
